Mrs. Doreatha Madison,
mother of five. ages 8 to IL,
and a high school dropout. proudly
marched with the graduating
class of 1864, at Paul Lawrence
Dunbar High School. Lynchburg,
Virginia, recently.


In addition to receiving her
high school diploma Mrs. Madi-
son who wants to become a pro-
fessional nurse, received the
coveted "Modess Incentive
Award" from Mrs. Alma John
who is a consultant for the Per-
sonal Products Company, Mill
town. New Jersey.


Mrs. John said, character,
community services and scholar
ship" Too many good average
students are lost because they
lack decent clothing, money for
food, transportation and the basic
necessities of life.''


MIR. and Mrs. Madison work
in a general hospital at night in
order to make ends meet.
twill use the cash award to
further her education


MIR. Seay, Principal of Dunbar
and Mrs. Pauline Weeden, assis-
tant principal. stated that Mrs.
Madison had done more to
motivate students to stay in
school than hundred speeches
on the sub ect.

Joseph, Uncle Joe) Clovese,
the last surviving Negro veteran
of the Union Army in the Civil
War. died at the age of l07,
July l3, 1913, at Dearborn, Mich.

Lost Negro
OF Union Army
Died 81 Years Ago

Franklin, farewell family and friends
Union Station Sunday morning.
She will Mr.. and Mrs. c. L. Scott her cousins in Newark
New Jersey
Miss Franklin Mrs. Lucinda Johnson Peggy
Johnson and Mrs. Gladys Mundy.

full articles.article:
Mrs. Doreatha Madison,
mother of five. ages 8 to IL,
and a high school dropout. proudly
marched with the graduating
class of 1864, at Paul Lawrence
Dunbar High School. Lynchburg,
Virginia, recently.


In addition to receiving her
high school diploma Mrs. Madi-
son who wants to become a pro-
fessional nurse, received the
coveted "Modess Incentive
Award" from Mrs. Alma John
who is a consultant for the Per-
sonal Products Company, Mill
town. New Jersey.


Mrs. John said, character,
community services and scholar
ship" Too many good average
students are lost because they
lack decent clothing, money for
food, transportation and the basic
necessities of life.''


MIR. and Mrs. Madison work
in a general hospital at night in
order to make ends meet.
twill use the cash award to
further her education


MIR. Seay, Principal of Dunbar
and Mrs. Pauline Weeden, assis-
tant principal. stated that Mrs.
Madison had done more to
motivate students to stay in
school than hundred speeches
on the sub ect.
